subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4 and public classes
msgSnippet: Elliotte ... My first workaround for this problem is to: - make the private method public (or package, or protected), and - annotate it with @TestPrivateShared
messageBody:
Elliotte

> Will JUnit 4 make it possible to have non-public test classes and test
> methods?


My first workaround for this problem is to:
- make the private method public (or package, or protected),
and
- annotate it with @TestPrivateShared - *1 -
- use an IDEA editor inspections pair - *1- to enforce the new
constraint.

(*1: that I created)

A first inspection highlights/tags as error any attempt to use a
@TestOnly field/method/class by production code that is not in the same
class
(== enforce the private aspect)

A second inspection finds in the code all the fields/methods/classes
that could be private, if it were not for tests, and tag them with
@TestPrivateShared.


My second workaround is to add a public method to the tested class, that
is only to be used by test code.
private Bar foo (){
...
}

@TestOnly
public Bar fooTestHook (){
return foo();
}


To make sure that no production code uses 'fooTestHook', I use another
pair of editor inspections.
Note: @TestOnly can decorate a field, method or even entire class.


Alain Ravet
